content:
Some context: https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/89167#issuecomment-933031740
So Mark raised this idea, since I mentioned a future final state for rust-lang/portable-simd might be "archived, the work is totally merged in to rust-lang/rust", of just merging it all in right now and shutting down rust-lang/portable-simd right away: https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/89167#issuecomment-933063065

Now, that would be low-cost for me, and Mark isn't requiring it... but it would make Mark a little happier. However, I am getting the impression that this might be a sudden workflow-breaking cost-raising change for everyone else and I don't wanna inflict that right away, least of all while we are still working things out.

mentioning this here just to broadcast my thoughts on possible endpoints for this project a little more loudly and so I can check to make sure I don't have some massive disagreement of "no let's move it all into core right away and have to rebuild rustc for minor changes" from @Caleb Zulawski <_<;
FWIW, if it's still all unstable, I would be in favor of a libs team "delegation" so that you can approve changes in that specific area as long as that doesn't have any stabilizations.
That would potentially reduce the workflow overhead.
The lang team has a similar understanding with the const eval working group.
It has less to do with that and more to do with "building the compiler is a lot" IME.
I think it's probably not the best to move it right now, particularly because of the separate test suite and fairly common major changes
One benefit of it being a separate repo is we can collaborate on relatively large changes more easily without pushing it upstream
as long as it's not an excessive amount of additional work for the main compiler people, a separate repo is much better
Cool. Yeah, it doesn't seem to be a dealbreaker either way, I mostly just figured I'd make sure I am in-tune.

Jubilee said:

It has less to do with that and more to do with "building the compiler is a lot" IME.

Ah. So the concern would be that folks developing it would have to build the whole compiler, and wouldn't be able to build just that one crate to test it?
We could make CI ensure that cargo test in that crate works...
I don't think that arrangement would satisfy the intent of Mark's observation.
